Gemini did a bit poorly compared to ChatGPT and Claude in this limited writing samples, potentially because I am using a free version of the LLM. I am slightly biased towards ChatGPT's responses, it includes relevant content I expect to see. It also included graphics to illustrate CDC crossings. In my coding experiments, I find Claude Code is usually fast but leaves holes, whereas ChatGPT Codex is more thorough.

prompts.title: AI Writing Tools
prompts.prompt: What is the best writing tool for technical blogs and articles, between Gemini, ChatGPT, and Claude?

responses.gemini:
Choosing the "best" tool for technical writing depends on where you are in the writing process‚Äîresearching, drafting, or coding. In 2026, the consensus among technical content creators is that while Claude produces the best prose, Gemini is the strongest for research, and ChatGPT remains the most versatile all-rounder.

**Side-by-Side Comparison**

| Feature | Claude (Opus/Sonnet 4.5) | Gemini (3 Pro/Advanced) | ChatGPT (GPT-5.2/o1) |
|---------|--------------------------|-------------------------|----------------------|
| Writing Style | Winner. Human-like, nuanced, and avoids "AI-isms." | Informative and structured; great for tutorials. | Versatile but can feel "robotic" or overly cheerful. |
| Technical Accuracy | High. Excellent at complex logic and code refactoring. | Strong, especially for Google/Android stacks. | Good, but prone to "hallucinating" outdated libraries. |
| Context Window | Large (200K+). Great for analyzing existing docs. | Winner (1M+). Best for summarizing entire repos. | Medium (128K-400K). Best for discrete, modular tasks. |
| Research Power | Limited real-time web access. | Winner. Native Google Search integration is elite. | Strong via SearchGPT, but less "multimodal." |
| Unique Feature | Artifacts: Side-by-side code/preview window. | Workspace Integration: Direct export to Google Docs. | Canvas: Interactive, inline editing of drafts. |

**Which One Should You Use?**

**1. Choose Claude for: The "Human" Polish**
If your goal is to write a deep-dive architectural piece or an opinionated technical essay, Claude is the gold standard. It has the best "ear" for tone and is least likely to use fluff.

Best for: Technical documentation, white papers, and complex debugging tutorials.

The Edge: It follows instructions for "clean code" better than its peers, ensuring your snippets are production-ready.

**2. Choose Gemini for: Research & Large Repos**
If your article requires pulling data from recent API releases, YouTube tutorials, or analyzing a 50-file GitHub repository, Gemini is the best choice.

Best for: "State of the Industry" reports, tutorials on brand-new frameworks, and ecosystem-heavy guides (GCP, Firebase).

The Edge: The ability to "talk to your codebase" via its massive context window makes it a superior research assistant.

**3. Choose ChatGPT for: Speed & Structure**
ChatGPT remains the most efficient tool for brainstorming outlines, generating SEO-friendly metadata, and creating marketing-focused technical blogs.

Best for: Quick "How-to" blogs, LinkedIn technical summaries, and rapid prototyping.

The Edge: Its Canvas feature allows you to highlight specific paragraphs and ask for technical rewrites without regenerating the whole article.

**The Professional Workflow**
Most high-end technical writers in 2026 don't pick just one; they use a "Model Stack":

1. Research & Outline: Use Gemini to scan documentation and YouTube for the latest updates.
2. Drafting: Use Claude to write the technical sections and code explanations for clarity.
3. Refining: Use ChatGPT's Canvas to polish the intro/outro and optimize for SEO.
responses.chatgpt:
There isn't a universally agreed single best model for writing technical blogs and articles ‚Äî instead, each of ChatGPT, Gemini, and Claude has strengths depending on what you emphasize (e.g., clarity, detail, research depth, integration with tools). Here's a structured comparison based on recent third-party analyses and reported user experiences:

**üìä 1. ChatGPT (OpenAI) ‚Äî Best All-Around Writing and Structure**

*Strengths*
‚Ä¢ Strong general-purpose writing quality ‚Äî clear explanations, structured output, and conversational editing help.
‚Ä¢ Excellent with complex writing tasks including marketing, documentation, and technical content.
‚Ä¢ Flexible across styles and formats with good prompt controls.

*Considerations*
‚Ä¢ Can be less specialized for deep enterprise publishing than Claude in some edge cases.

*Best for*
‚úî Online technical articles, tutorials, and documentation
‚úî Broad topic coverage with integrated reasoning
‚úî Writers who want a balance of clarity, structure, and tone

**üß† Claude (Anthropic) ‚Äî Best for Deep, Structured Writing**

*Strengths*
‚Ä¢ Frequently praised for clarity, coherence, and detailed long-form content.
‚Ä¢ Tends to produce thoughtful, well-reasoned prose that suits technical explanations and analysis.
‚Ä¢ Often preferred in research-heavy contexts and high-stakes writing.

*Considerations*
‚Ä¢ Lacks the multimodal and ecosystem integration (e.g., search, workplace tools) of Gemini or ChatGPT.

*Best for*
‚úî In-depth, technical explanations and analytical pieces
‚úî Academic-style writing or tightly argued content
‚úî Writers who value precision and structured detail

**üîç Gemini (Google) ‚Äî Strong for Research-Linked Writing**

*Strengths*
‚Ä¢ Integrates closely with search and Google ecosystem (Docs, Gmail), giving good real-time research context.
‚Ä¢ Good at pulling up-to-date information, summaries, and references.

*Considerations*
‚Ä¢ Some comparative tests find it produces less detailed narrative out of the box than ChatGPT or Claude.

*Best for*
‚úî Articles that require current facts and citations
‚úî Writers who leverage Google Workspace in their workflow
‚úî Research-heavy drafts you want to flesh out quickly

**üß© Summary Guideline**
| Priority | Best Pick |
|----------|----------|
| Deep, structured technical writing | Claude |
| Balanced style + broad topic coverage | ChatGPT |
| Research + real-time info integration | Gemini |

**üìå Practical Recommendation**
‚Ä¢ If your priority is clarity, coherence, and polished technical prose: start with Claude.
‚Ä¢ If you need flexibility and broad capability (writing + editing + brainstorming): go with ChatGPT.
‚Ä¢ If your draft requires current research and tool integration: use Gemini, possibly in combination with another model to refine style.

**üîÑ Bonus: Combined Workflow (often best in practice)**
Many professional writers use multiple tools:
1. Gemini for initial research and fact gathering
2. Claude for drafting detailed sections
3. ChatGPT for polishing, structure, and editing

This hybrid approach often yields the most reliable and publishable technical content.
responses.claude:
I should be upfront: I'm one of the options here, so I have an inherent bias. That said, I can offer some honest observations:

**Each has different strengths:**

**Claude (me):** I tend to be strong at longer-form, nuanced writing with attention to structure and clarity. I'm generally good at maintaining a consistent voice and following detailed stylistic instructions. I also tend to be careful about accuracy and will flag when I'm uncertain.

**ChatGPT:** Has strong general writing capabilities and a massive user base, which means lots of community resources, plugins, and integrations. The GPT-4 variants are solid all-around performers for technical content.

**Gemini:** Benefits from tight Google integration, which can be useful if you're working within the Google ecosystem. It has strong capabilities for research-adjacent tasks given its access to Google Search.

**The honest answer:** "Best" depends heavily on your specific workflow, what you're writing about, and personal preference. Many technical writers use multiple tools and find each shines in different contexts. The differences between top-tier models have narrowed considerably‚Äîall three can produce good technical content.

**My suggestion:** Try all three with the same technical article prompt and see which output resonates with your style and needs. Most have free tiers that let you experiment. Your own judgment of the results will be more useful than any recommendation I can give, especially since I can't objectively evaluate myself against competitors.

What kind of technical content are you writing? I might be able to offer more specific thoughts.

prompts.title: Formal Verification
prompts.prompt: Write three paragraphs about what is formal verification, how it is different from simulation, where it can be used for.

responses.gemini:
**Understanding Formal Verification**

Formal Verification is a rigorous mathematical approach used to prove that a hardware or software system satisfies a specific set of requirements or properties. Unlike traditional testing, which relies on trial and error, formal verification uses mathematical logic to exhaustively analyze the system's design. By creating a formal model of the system and expressing its intended behavior through logic formulas, engineers can use automated tools‚Äîsuch as model checkers or theorem provers‚Äîto ensure that the system will function correctly under every possible set of inputs and conditions. It essentially turns "I think this works" into "I can prove this works."

The fundamental difference between formal verification and simulation (or testing) lies in coverage. Simulation involves running the system with a specific set of input vectors to see if it produces the correct output; however, as systems grow in complexity, the number of possible states becomes astronomical, making it impossible to test every scenario. This leaves "corner cases" where bugs can hide. Formal verification, conversely, does not use test vectors. Instead, it explores the entire state space of the design simultaneously. While simulation can show the presence of bugs, formal verification is designed to prove their total absence within the defined properties.

Because of its high level of certainty, formal verification is primarily used in safety-critical and mission-critical domains where failure is not an option. It is a staple in semiconductor design (ASICs and FPGAs) to prevent multi-billion dollar hardware recalls, and in aerospace and automotive engineering for flight control and autonomous driving systems. Beyond hardware, it is increasingly applied to smart contracts in blockchain to prevent exploits, and in the development of secure microkernels where a single vulnerability could compromise an entire network. Any environment where the "cost of failure" outweighs the "cost of proof" is a prime candidate for this methodology.
responses.chatgpt:
Formal verification is a mathematically rigorous approach to verifying the correctness of hardware and systems designs. Instead of testing a design with selected input scenarios, formal verification models the design and its requirements as mathematical objects and then proves whether the requirements always hold. These requirements are typically expressed as properties‚Äîsuch as safety ("this bad thing never happens") or liveness ("this good thing eventually happens")‚Äîwritten in assertion languages. If a property fails, formal tools produce a precise counterexample showing exactly how and why the failure occurs, making root-cause analysis highly deterministic.

Formal verification differs fundamentally from simulation in both methodology and coverage. Simulation validates a design by executing it over time with specific test vectors, which means it can only observe behaviors that are explicitly exercised. Even with extensive regression suites, simulation inevitably leaves gaps because the input space and state space are too large to exhaustively explore. Formal verification, by contrast, explores all possible legal behaviors of the design within the defined constraints, without requiring testbenches or stimulus. This makes formal especially powerful for corner cases, complex control logic, concurrency, and scenarios that are extremely difficult‚Äîor practically impossible‚Äîto reach with simulation alone.

Formal verification is commonly used for block-level and system-level verification tasks where completeness and correctness are critical. Typical applications include control logic validation, protocol compliance, arbitration and coherency logic, security properties, low-power intent checking, and equivalence checking between different design representations (such as RTL-to-RTL or RTL-to-gate). It is also widely applied in safety-critical domains like automotive, aerospace, and industrial systems, as well as in advanced SoC designs where state explosion makes simulation insufficient. In practice, formal verification complements simulation: simulation excels at validating data-path behavior and performance under realistic workloads, while formal provides exhaustive guarantees for correctness-sensitive logic.
responses.claude:
Formal verification is a mathematical approach to proving that a system‚Äîwhether hardware or software‚Äîbehaves correctly according to its specification. Rather than running test cases and checking outputs, formal verification uses mathematical logic, theorem proving, and model checking to exhaustively analyze all possible states and behaviors of a design. The goal is to provide a rigorous proof that certain properties always hold (such as "the system never deadlocks" or "this variable never exceeds a given value") or to find a counterexample that demonstrates a bug. Because it reasons about the design abstractly, formal verification can catch corner-case bugs that would be nearly impossible to encounter through random or directed testing.

The key difference between formal verification and simulation lies in coverage. Simulation runs a finite set of test vectors through a model and observes whether the outputs match expectations‚Äîit can only check the specific scenarios you test. Even with millions of test cycles, simulation explores only a tiny fraction of the possible state space of a complex design. Formal verification, by contrast, considers all reachable states simultaneously through symbolic reasoning. If a formal tool says a property holds, it means the property holds for every possible input sequence, not just the ones someone thought to test. The tradeoff is that formal methods can be computationally expensive and may struggle with very large state spaces, which is why the two approaches are often used together: simulation for broad functional testing and formal methods for targeted verification of critical properties.

Formal verification is widely used in domains where correctness is paramount and bugs carry severe consequences. In hardware design, it verifies processor pipelines, cache coherence protocols, bus arbitration logic, and security-critical control paths. In software, it appears in verified compilers, operating system kernels, cryptographic implementations, and safety-critical embedded systems for aerospace and automotive applications. The technique is also essential in protocol verification, where it can prove that communication protocols maintain properties like mutual exclusion or freedom from livelock. As designs grow more complex and the cost of post-silicon bugs increases, formal verification has shifted from a niche specialty to a standard part of the verification toolkit in many industries.

prompts.title: CDC Verification
prompts.prompt: Explain what is clock domain crossing verification and why it is important

responses.gemini:
In the world of high-performance hardware design, Clock Domain Crossing (CDC) occurs when data is transferred from a logic block driven by one clock signal to another block driven by a different, asynchronous clock. Because these clocks may have different frequencies or phases, the destination registers may capture the data at the exact moment it is changing.

**The Science of the "Glitch": Metastability**

The primary reason CDC verification is critical is a physical phenomenon called metastability. In digital logic, a flip-flop needs a stable input for a specific window (setup and hold time) to correctly register a "0" or a "1."

When a signal crosses a clock boundary asynchronously, the destination clock may sample the data right as it toggles. This causes the transistor to enter a state where the output voltage hovers between high and low, neither a logical 0 nor 1. This "unsettled" state can propagate through the rest of the chip, leading to unpredictable behavior, system hangs, or corrupted data.

**Why CDC Verification is Mandatory**

Traditional functional simulation often fails to catch CDC issues because simulators assume "ideal" timing. CDC verification is vital for several reasons:

‚Ä¢ **Non-Deterministic Failures:** Metastability is probabilistic. A chip might work perfectly in the lab but crash once every 100 hours in the field due to a specific thermal or voltage condition.

‚Ä¢ **The Inadequacy of Testing:** Since simulation doesn't usually model the random phase shifts between clocks, you can have 100% code coverage and still have a "broken" design.

‚Ä¢ **Data Integrity:** In multi-core processors or complex SoCs (Systems on Chip), data must move between different speeds (e.g., a fast CPU and a slower peripheral). Without proper synchronizers (like 2-stage flip-flops or Handshake protocols), the data can be "sampled" twice or missed entirely.

**How Verification is Performed**

Engineers use Structural CDC Analysis tools to scan the Netlist or RTL code. These tools look for:

‚Ä¢ **Unsynchronized Crossings:** Signals moving between domains without a recognized synchronization scheme.

‚Ä¢ **Convergence:** Multiple signals crossing and then combining, which can cause "re-convergence glitches" where the timing relationship between those bits is lost.

‚Ä¢ **Complex Protocols:** Ensuring that FIFOs (First-In-First-Out buffers) used for crossing data have correctly synchronized read/write pointers.
responses.chatgpt:
Clock Domain Crossing (CDC) verification is the process of ensuring that signals transferred between different clock domains in a digital design behave correctly and reliably. A clock domain is defined by a clock signal and its associated timing assumptions; when data moves from one domain to another with a different clock (frequency, phase, or even asynchronous relationship), standard synchronous timing guarantees no longer apply. Without proper handling, these crossings can lead to metastability, data corruption, or intermittent functional failures that may only appear in silicon. CDC verification focuses on identifying all such crossings and checking that appropriate synchronization or communication schemes are used.

CDC issues arise because a signal launched by one clock can be sampled at an unsafe time by another clock. If the sampling occurs near a transition, the receiving flip-flop can enter a metastable state, producing unpredictable results that may propagate through the design. To mitigate this, designers use well-known structures such as multi-flop synchronizers for single-bit control signals, handshaking protocols for coordinated transfers, and asynchronous FIFOs for multi-bit data paths. CDC verification checks not only that these structures exist, but that they are used correctly‚Äîfor example, ensuring synchronizers are not optimized away, control signals are not treated as data buses, and FIFO pointers are safely synchronized.

CDC verification is important because CDC bugs are among the hardest to detect with simulation. They depend on precise clock alignment and rare timing conditions that are unlikely to be exercised by testbenches, yet can cause catastrophic failures in real hardware. Static CDC analysis and formal CDC verification exhaustively analyze the design structure to flag unsafe crossings, missing synchronizers, reconvergence issues, and protocol violations‚Äîwithout requiring stimulus. In modern SoCs with dozens or hundreds of clock domains driven by power management, performance scaling, and IP reuse, CDC verification is essential to achieve robust, silicon-proven designs and to avoid costly late-stage or post-silicon failures.
responses.claude:
Clock domain crossing verification is the process of ensuring that signals passing between different clock domains in a digital design are handled correctly and do not cause functional failures. In modern chips, it is common to have multiple clock domains‚Äîregions of logic operating on different clocks that may vary in frequency, phase, or source. Whenever a signal originating in one clock domain is sampled by logic in another, there is an inherent risk of metastability: the receiving flip-flop may capture the signal during its transition, causing the output to settle to an unpredictable value or oscillate before resolving. CDC verification identifies all points where signals cross domain boundaries and checks that appropriate synchronization structures, such as two-flop synchronizers, handshake protocols, or asynchronous FIFOs, are in place to mitigate these risks.

The importance of CDC verification stems from the fact that metastability-related bugs are notoriously difficult to detect through simulation. Because metastability is a probabilistic electrical phenomenon that depends on precise timing relationships, a simulation running with ideal timing models will almost never expose it. A design can pass millions of simulation cycles and still fail intermittently in silicon when signals happen to change at exactly the wrong moment relative to the receiving clock edge. These failures are sporadic, temperature-dependent, and extremely hard to debug after fabrication. CDC verification tools use static analysis to examine the design structurally, flagging missing or improper synchronizers, reconvergence issues where multiple CDC paths recombine unsafely, and control signals that lack proper synchronization even when data paths are protected.

Beyond metastability, CDC verification also catches subtler problems related to data coherency and protocol correctness. For example, a multi-bit bus crossing a clock boundary without proper encoding or handshaking can arrive with different bits updating at different times, producing transient garbage values. Similarly, control signals that are supposed to be mutually exclusive may temporarily violate that constraint when viewed from the receiving domain. Thorough CDC verification examines reset synchronization, gray-code correctness on FIFO pointers, pulse synchronization for single-cycle strobes, and the structural integrity of handshake state machines. Because fixing CDC bugs in silicon is often impossible without a respin, catching these issues during RTL verification is critical to avoiding costly schedule delays and ensuring the chip functions reliably across all operating conditions.

title: Data & Metrics Review
description: Analyzing product usage and business data
why: Data-driven decisions lead to better product outcomes
howAiHelps: AI enables natural language queries on dashboards and automatically surfaces insights from complex datasets
recommendation: I have explored a few options. Given we are in the Microsoft ecosystem and spreadsheet centric, Power BI offers sufficient features for our day to day use.

tools.name: Power BI
tools.description: Natural language Q&A and AI-powered insights on dashboards

detailedContent.title: What Power BI Adds Beyond Excel (in plain terms)

sections.heading: 1. Interactive Dashboards (not static charts)
sections.intro: Excel charts are mostly static. Power BI dashboards are fully interactive.
bullets: Click one bar ‚Üí entire dashboard filters
Slice by customer, product, region, time instantly
Drill down (Year ‚Üí Quarter ‚Üí Month) without new charts
sections.note: This is night and day for management reviews.

sections.heading: 2. Automatic Data Modeling
sections.intro: In Excel, you manually VLOOKUP/XLOOKUP, maintain pivot relationships, and risk broken formulas.
bullets: Understands customers, products, dates as entities
sections.note: This matters when data grows or changes.

sections.heading: 3. DAX = Business Logic Layer
sections.intro: Excel formulas are cell-based. Power BI uses DAX, which is context-aware.
bullets: Revenue per customer within selected filters
Time intelligence (YoY, MoM, rolling averages) with one formula
sections.note: In Excel, this is fragile and repetitive.

sections.heading: 4. True What-If Analysis (Sliders, Not Copies)
sections.intro: Excel what-if usually means duplicate sheets, scenario tables, and manual toggling.
sections.note: This is huge for leadership conversations.

sections.heading: 5. Always-Up-to-Date Dashboards
sections.intro: Excel: someone emails a file, forgets to refresh, versions get out of sync.
sections.note: This alone justifies Power BI in many orgs.

sections.heading: 6. Executive-Grade Visuals
sections.intro: Excel visuals are fine. Power BI visuals are designed for decision-making.
bullets: Drill-through pages per customer or product
sections.note: These are difficult or clunky in Excel.

sections.heading: 7. Governance & Sharing
sections.intro: Excel: files get copied, logic gets modified accidentally, access control is weak.
bullets: Shared dashboards without exposing raw data

excelAdvantages.title: What Excel Is Still Better At
excelAdvantages.intro: Power BI is not a replacement for everything. Excel wins at:
excelAdvantages.conclusion: Best practice: Excel ‚Üí analyze, Power BI ‚Üí communicate and decide

otherTools.note: More targeted for exploration and discovering insights with advanced visuals
